node.text:
How do we build resiliency in our children? Three take aways from this live with @drbeckyathome:
1️⃣Model resiliency 
2️⃣Name and value those “perfect” feelings our kids have
3️⃣Talk about our own failures

node.text:
HOW DO WE HELP KIDS LISTEN?
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
This has to be one of the most asked questions whenever I do a Q&A: how do I get my kids to listen better? How do I help them be better listeners?
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
The listening dilemma is one where you are definitely not alone ❤️ “In one ear, out the other” never made quite as much sense until I became a parent 😂
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Today, I’m sharing five tips that I use with my family (and back when I was a teacher) to help kids listen better and reduce that parent / caregiver frustration that comes along with it 🤪
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Check out my 5 TIPS FOR HELPING KIDS LISTEN video 👆🏻 Just a few changes can make a huge difference.

node.text: ⏰OUR WAKE UP ROUTINE⏰ This is NOT an ad for tiny kid clocks 😂 although maybe I could have a side hustle as a product model? 🤷🏻‍♀️ I think I'll stick to my activities day job 😂 I have been SLAMMED (I say this lovingly) with questions lately about kids waking up in the morning, helping kids stay in beds/rooms, and ending the ‪5 am‬ "It's too early to wake up" shuffle 😱 I talk about this in my DAILY ROUTINE post (link in profile @busytoddler) but I wanted to give even more explanation 😊 My kids have these "OK TO WAKE" clocks - Mirari brand from Amazon (this company doesn't even have an IG so believe me when I say they do not know who I am) 😉 In this video, I explain the difference between the two clocks and how we use them with our kids. 👍🏻The clocks turn BRIGHT GREEN (with or without a sound) at whatever time we set them for in the AM 👊🏻 With one of our kids, this is his "it's now OK to leave your room" clock and it turns green ‪at 7:30 am‬ ➡️ For our other kids, this is their “it's OK TO WAKE, it's no longer ‪4 am‬" clocks - and it turns green ‪at 6:30 am‬ signalling to them that they are now free to play quietly in their rooms 😍 As I say in the video and the blog post (link in profile @busytoddler), our kids have safe toys in their rooms, anchored furniture, and a totally kid-approved area to play 🙌🏻 We trained them all to stay in their rooms until either we come to get them or the green light goes on ‪at 7:30 am‬ 💜 We trained them using firm, clear, and consistent boundaries - making this a big priority in our morning parenting - and for the first little bit after the crib to bed transition, we did have toddler locks on their doors for safety (I don't need a 22 month old wandering my house alone ‪at midnight‬) ❤️Obviously, we have video monitors so we can see them, and as always, do what is best / right for your family, practice safe habits, and use your judgment 🎉 In the video, I answer the big question of "don't they wake up hungry?" and in the blog post, you can find information on what I do after potty training (hint: tiny toddler toilet...) 🙌🏻 I hope our routine can help you find and develop the best wake up routine for your family 😘

node.text:
WOW - It's been almost a week since I was on GOOD MORNING AMERICA (@goodmorningamerica) and the feeling is still surreal...like I'm watching some other Mom talk about rice bins on national TV. 
I have so much to be thankful for this year - I can't even begin to list it all out. This moment, being on GMA, it really drove home just how incredible this journey has been for me. You see, my last trip to NYC (before this one) was back in 2012 with my husband, Chuck. It was a much needed getaway at a time when things were really heavy in our lives. Even though we were away on vacation, we had to pause during our trip to handle real life: we sat in a park by the Brookyln Bridge and filled out the paperwork for our 5th and final round of IVF. 
Before that, I had always thought parenthood was just this right we had and I'd never considered what it would be like to have to fight so hard for something that seemed so natural. I was so naive. That day, in New York, we didn't know if parenting was in the cards for us or what more it would take to get us there, but we were pushing forward fighting for something we believed we were destined for. Fast forward a few months and our miracle Sam was born. The final round worked and we'd made it to "parenthood". How poetic to then be back in New York, seven years later, and brought there as a sort-of "parenting expert". Me? This Mom who almost wasn't. I have so much to be thankful for and so many people to thank (I can start with the 657k of you...). Life doesn't always take the path we expect, and I am living proof of that. Thank you from the bottom of my heart for joining me on my parenting journey and for all the magic that's come with it. Happy Thanksgiving, Friends. 
With love and gratitude, Susie

node.title: Busy Toddler on Good Morning America

node.text: 🌟TRAVEL KIT🌟 aka the restaurant kit, the waiting room kit, the car ride kit, the saving my sanity since 2016 kit 🎉🎉🎉 Do you have a kit like this that's your go-to? 🙌🏻 Here's mine that I always have stocked and ready - it's a grab and go type thing - and it’s perfect for holiday events as we enter that season 🦃🎄There's a whole lot of method to the madness of what I have stored tightly into this little kit 👍🏻 The first time I made this, I had a 3 year old, a 19 month old, was having a c-section in two weeks and needed to keep my kids entertained at a company dinner for Chuck 😳 No pressure 😂 So I whipped this up before we left and our so-called “restaurant kit” has lived in my car ever since for moments when we need a little back up 💃🏻 I put all my years of Tetris & Nintendo-ing into packing this thing TIGHT 🤣. It all started with this small wipes container (like Cottonelle, Charmin,  or Scott's brand) - the container is the backbone of this operation because 1️⃣ the container can open and shut easy 2️⃣ The slit on top is perfect for shoving things through 3️⃣ It's jusssst the right size ✨ I have it full of post-it notes, dot stickers, tiny animals, match box cars, playing cards, crayons, and a partridge in a pear tree 😂Ok maybe not the last one😂 But seriously, this kit is EVERYTHING for us 🌟 the thing is: I have three kids and don't have three cell phones so a kit like this is crucial for when we go out places 🎉 I want them to learn to be a part of the action, conversation, the waiting, etc and this helps facilitate that for us - gives us a little more to do as we pass the time ⏰ What's in your "travel kit"? 🤔What's a must for your family when you go out? 🤔 Let’s pack the comments full of ideas so we can all make some amazing kits to help us during this week of car rides, dinners, and travel 🙌🏻🙌🏻🙌🏻 #busytoddleractivities

node.text:
SENSORY BINS 101 - Alright class! It's time for Busy Toddler School - jk but how fun would that be?! Let's talk all things sensory bins today - aka my most favorite activity for kids. Sensory bins are the great equalizers of play - from 12 months old to 12 years old... kids love sensory bins.

But there's a lot of questions around them: how do you make one? What do kids learn from them? And (most important) how do we keep kids from making GIANT messes with the supplies? 
I made a little video for IGTV to answer all those bin questions. Nothing holds my kids' attention quite like a sensory bin... and I want to share that magic with you all.

Cheers to happy, playing kids! XOXO - Susie

#busytoddleractivities #sensorybins #sensoryplay #earlychildhood #letthemplay

node.text:
Learned this idea from @andnextcomesl YEARS ago ♥️
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Don’t toss those water balloon attachments just yet - use them as tiny bubble blowers!
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Just dip them in bubble solution, swirl it around, and BLOW! It’s a fun, extra way to play with bubbles ☀️☀️
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
(Just promise me you’ll use cleaner bubble solution than the lady on the Internet did 🤣🤣🤢🪰)

node.accessibility_caption: Childhood is not a race to see how quickly a child can read, write or count. It is a small window of time to learn and develop at the pace that is right for each individual child. -Magda Gerber

node.text:
You don’t need me to tell you this: I know you feel it, but just in case:
Childhood is short.
Childhood is precious.
Childhood isn't a race to some arbitrary finish line. 
And we all know there's no prize for finishing childhood first.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
It is a small window of time we are parenting in (a fast, fleeting, exhilarating, and wonder-filled time), and a small window of time they are growing in. It isn't meant to be rushed or hurried or pushed ahead. 
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Enjoy the window.
Enjoy the pace.
Enjoy the small moments, friends.

node.accessibility_caption: Childhood is not a race to see how quickly a child can read, write or count. It is a small window of time to learn and develop at the pace that is right for each individual child. -Magda Gerber
Photo by Susie Allison | Busy Toddler on July 16, 2021. May be an image of 4 people, child and indoor.

Do this: Not this: In the next few Do not rush to weeks, hug your pull out flashcards, child. Play games, workbooks, or buy read books, take computer programs walks, and have to get kids conversations ready for around the table. kindergarten. SYATODDLER'.

node.text:
But also make sure they know how to wipe 😉
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Kindergarten is coming. I’ve been a first day kindergarten parent. I’ve been a kindergarten teacher. I’ve had stakes in both sides of this coin ♥️ In my profile, it’s my post on kindergarten readiness skills (spoiler: they aren’t academic) if you’d like a list to read (@busytoddler).
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Friends, nothing boils me more than the commercials I hear preying on the fears of parents with kindergarteners - pushing ideas into minds about what kids need to be successful. Please do not get swayed. They are making money on fear.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
What gets missed from all those advertising messages is this: that kindergarteners need life and social skills MORE than memorized academics. That life and social skills in kindergarten are a far bigger determinant to a child’s future success than how fast they can state letters or numbers.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
As kindergarten approaches, lean into your child: take walks together, talk about life, listen to them, play games, read all the books, start a giant puzzle, and visit playgrounds. We can do so much for kindergarten readiness by just helping them develop as people and grow into who they are meant to be.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
If kindergarten is coming up fast for you, take a deep breath. You have done so much for this child over these years. It’s time. Time to let them stand. Time to let them walk in front. Time to see them in a whole new light ♥️
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
If you want a specific list of skills: check out the link in my profile for my Kindergarten Readiness List (@busytoddler )

They love to tell us we need them. They love to exploit our fears that our children will fall behind. Do not listen to them. BUSY ATODDLER 1'.

Photo by Susie Allison | Busy Toddler on July 14, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Kindergarten is a time of huge growth. Professional teachers are waiting to help your child learn foundational skills for their education when they get to school. What will help your child today? Having a secure relationship with you. Having listened to countless books. Having been challenged by puzzles. Having learned about winning and losing at board games. Having built resilience on the playground. Having life and social skills. BUSY TODDLER'.

Photo by Susie Allison | Busy Toddler on July 14, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Block out the noise of the next few weeks. Don't listen to the companies and advertisements hoping to cash in. Enjoy this time time with your child. you Be together. Hold tight. Love each other. And walk forward into kindergarten knowing they are ready to stand on their own and take these independent steps without you. BUSY ATODDLER'.

node.text:
Shout out to everyone with a taby this summer 🙌🏻 I see you and District 12 salute you.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Taby definition: (TAY•BEE) A child who is no longer a baby but not quite a toddler yet ⭐️ It's a little like developmental purgatory. 
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
There is a major distinction between the skills of (for example) a 14-month-old verses a full blow two-year-old toddler ➡️And I think we should honor this group of kids by acknowledging this stage. They have all the ideas of a toddler but none of the motor skills to make it happen 😭 It's a tough spot for them and for those who love them. The taby stage is amazing, magical, frustrating, hard, and wonderful all at the same time ♥️♥️♥️
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Now, there's no hard and fast line in and out of taby-hood - you'll know the day when they tip the scales officially into toddlerhood and leave baby fully behind 😭
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
And for this group, they get their own subset of activities ➡️
This is my favorite taby activity and a precious 16-month-old Kate working her chubby little cheeks away at it. Take a container and make a slit in the lid. Have them slip cards into the slot. You can be tricky and made the slot only work when the cards are vertical for a fun challenge... This hold taby attention spans like nothing else🤯
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Well, it holds it for like 5 minutes🤣 Anyone in the taby-land of life knows that 5 minutes is an eternity with that bunch.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Grab a container with a lid, get some playing cards, and make this up. Leave it sitting out if you can so taby has something to bounce back to throughout the day/week. It's an amazing little activity for an amazing group of kids 🥰

node.text:
Stop. Hammer time 🔨
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
100% our favorite summer activity, and we’ve been doing this since my oldest was a toddler 😱
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
THE SAFETY 411:
Have them wear sunglasses or other eye protection. Be safe, be smart, this is an activity from some lady on the Internet 😉
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
When Sam was 25 months old, I handed him some toddler hammers & let him go after some left over cooler ice. He loved it. By the end of that summer, I had 15 different hammers & mallets because every kid in the neighborhood (from age 25 months to 10 years) was obsessed with ice smashing.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Also I love this activity and always smash a few cubes 🤣
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
You know your child: kids need to learn hammering skills and this is a easy introduction (it’s a lot easier than a nail into wood). Set up boundaries & ground rules for this play, and enforce it. This is a great ALL AGES activity but it does take some solid direction following to keep everyone safe.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Next bag of ice or busted ice maker moment, dump out the ice, add tools, and let your kids have some hammer time 🎶

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Susie Allison | Busy Toddler on July 09, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'I never feel bad for what I can or can't give to each child. won't subscribe to that guilt. Yes, my oldest had one on one time with Mom, out my youngest gets the most experienced Mom. There are birth order trade-offs, but it'll even out in the end. -Susie Allison BUSY TODDLER'.

node.text:
And for my middle, she always has a companion and has a *slightly* more experienced parent. It all evens out.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
I posted this sentiment to stories this week, and it resonated with so many parents.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
We worry up and down about what we can or can't give our children, and that's hard enough when we are comparing ourselves to the rest of the world through the social media window. But even harder when we start to compare from child to child in our own families too - and the guilt mounts over what we can (or can't) give to each.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
If this has been weighing on your heart, please take a minute today and shift that perspective.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
I know that's a tall ask, but try this: Instead of looking at what you can't give each child, look at what you do give or what they get. There's individual greatness being given to each of your children and that's ok.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀ ⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Here's how it sounds for me:
My oldest is paving the way. He had one-on-one time with me and he gets to go first. He knows how to teach others and share learning with them. My middle never knew life alone. She's always had a friend. Her parents had one round of experience under their belts and are a little wiser. She learns skills from her older sibling. My youngest has always had a loud house. His parents were the most experienced and they knew how to support him. He has two guides in life and knows how to advocate for himself.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
See? Three kids. Same parents. Different lives. And that's a good thing if you let it be one.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Take a minute today and reflect on the positives of your children's lives. Focus on releasing the negative and the guilt to do it all the same, because there's beauty to be found.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Susie Allison | Busy Toddler on July 07, 2021. May be an image of child, outdoors and text that says 'ICE ACTIVITIES ARE THE COOLEST Swipe for ideas'.

node.text:
Let's just start with the disclaimer from the lady on the Internet ➡️please use good judgement and supervision for your kids and ice.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Alright, we got that out of the way. Now let's talk about the fun 😘
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
I would also like to openly apologize for the pun on the first slide. I literally couldn't help myself 🤦🏻‍♀️
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Roll on through these images - here's what you're looking at ➡️

✨PAINT ICE: Seriously fun. Let the kids paint ice cubes with either watercolor paint or washable tempera paint. The paint freezes a bit as it hits the ice, but it's slick and smooth - it's awesome. We started doing this activity when Sam and Kate were 2 and 3 - still into it as big kids.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
✨SMASH ICE: Easily the favorite summer activity - but make sure to add eye protection. Dump out ice on the concrete and hand over some toy hammers or meat mallets. This activity is AMAZING. Sam has been smashing ice since he was a toddler and learned so much about the hammering skill from this activity. Now he's 8 and guess what he was doing with the left over cooler ice last week🤣 Use good judgment with your kids on this activity especially, but it really is amazing.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
✨SCOOP AND TRANSFER: I set this up for a 3-year-old Kate and it was a HUGE HIT. Half the bin has ice, the other half is a smaller bin with blue water (just to fancy). She would scoop the ice into the water, then scoop it back. This went on and on and on until we were left with water and it became a pouring station.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
✨ICE TABLE: Toss the ice, some water, and some toys into the water table. It's a great imaginary/pretend play activity that's a huge win. In this photo, it's an 18 month old Matt playing with 3 year old Kate. They had a ball.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Ice ice baby - it's the best in the summer and if you're anything like me: you either have left overs in coolers or have jammed the ice maker for the umpteenth time 🤣🤣🤣

Tired of the constant clean up battle? Try this instead: give them a number • pick up 15 items. Tell them which toy specifically • your job is the blocks. Pick up by color • you need to clean up all the green toys.

node.text:
Ever feel like you're just saying the words "clean up" into the void? Like the words are just bouncing off the walls of your home and gain traction with exactly no one 🤦🏻‍♀️
 ⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
I get it.
 ⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Here's the reason (and then the quick fix - click bait headline "the one weird trick to get your kids to clean up"): Saying "clean up" to kids - especially young kids - is both abstract and overwhelming. It's the wrong combination for this age. It's abstract in that "what does clean up mean - this room, the house, this toy bin?" and it's overwhelming because well, kids make great messes.
 ⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
So we fix that.
 ⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
First: we make clean up less abstract by defining exactly what we want to clean up and what we want the kids to actually accomplish. I used this trick in my classroom, in my home, and with all the neighbor kids - I give a SET NUMBER OF ITEMS TO PICK UP. When my 3 kids and me all pick up 13 items, that's 52 things and suddenly everything looks a lot better.
 ⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
It also makes it less overwhelming.
 ⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Not sure if numbers will work with your kiddo OR they've got too many small-part toys out for it to help (like blocks and magnetic tiles): identify the SPECIFIC area to clean. "Your job is the blocks. When you finish, I'll give you the next job." Manageable pieces to bite off.
 ⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Color is the same way (and super fun for toddlers): "Find all the blue toys and put them away." Hello, color vocabulary and visual discrimination WHILE cleaning. Holy learning in context, Batman.
 ⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
The next time the playroom, basement, backyard, bedroom, family room - you name it - needs a tidy up: Stop yourself from saying "Clean up" and instead give it a little twist that's more concrete, less abstract, and far less overwhelming.
 ⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
See: one weird trick really can help the kids clean up.

node.text:
All I wanna do is drink my morning coffee in peace ✌🏻🤣
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
This is an absolute gem to take outside this summer - and my kids, the neighbor kids, everyone is loving this set up (from toddler to elementary age… this has MASS appeal).
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
THE SET UP:
In a 28 qt bin from Target, I put 2 boxes of baking soda (bi-carb). Food coloring goes into the ice cube tray with white vinegar. I have some cute little pipettes (Amazon) but medicine droppers work great too ✨
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
LEAVE THIS OUT FOR THE KIDS and let them explore. Don’t be in a rush to put in a way (no joke, this set up has bought me a WEEK in our backyard 🤣 I just keep adding vinegar)
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
FOOD COLORING FAQ: it doesn’t stain because it’s diluted by the vinegar but even if it gets on skin or clothing, it rinses clean with cold water (set the clothes in a sink of water if you need to). Again, just the lady on the Internet but food coloring isn’t nearly as scary as it looks in activities 😘😘
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Enjoy this gem - it never gets old (unlike me 🤣👩🏻‍🦳)

node.text:
Hi Friends. I'm Susie and I run Busy Toddler. I thought I'd just say Hi - felt like a good day for a Hello.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
I'm the face behind the posts you see here. I started Busy Toddler in June 2015 on a complete and total whim. Heckuva whim, huh? I started out life as a teacher - I taught K and 1. My dream job. Then I had my first, stayed home with him, had my second, and thought I might never recover from 2 under 2. 
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
I've told you this before but I'll tell it again. One night, when I was a few weeks post-partum after my second, I decided I just had to make a fancy, nice, real dinner. I wanted to feel normal life again. Of course, it didn't go as planned: my toddler began destroying the kitchen, the baby started screaming, the dinner began to burn and in a moment of so much fluster - I dropped my cell phone in the dish water. I pulled it out, put it in a bag of rice to dry, and cried. Life didn't feel anywhere close to normal.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
A few days later, my phone worked again but I was left with all this rice that I couldn't cook with. I remembered vaguely this idea that kids could play in rice so I found an old storage container, emptied it out of the junk we didn't need, put my toddler and the rice into it and created my first sensory bin. 4 months later, I opened Busy Toddler on Instagram and the rest is well, history.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Never in my wildest dreams did I expect to be here, six years later. But this is where we are, and I’m having the time of my life. Thanks for being with me on this journey, for being a part of my family, and for allowing me to be even the smallest part of yours. It is a joy and honor that I will forever cherish.

node.text:
THE SAFETY TIP YOU NEED THIS SUMMER ⬇️⬇️
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
My husband and I have been using a cockpit safety measure for our whole span of parenting AND IT WORKS WONDERS. It keeps the kids safe, makes sure supervision is specified, and helps us never just assume the other adult is watching out. Chuck (who was an airline pilot back in our pre-kid days) started this system for us almost the day our first came home from the hospital.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
THE BACKSTORY: When airline pilots need to make a change of controls in the cockpit, the pilot currently flying says: "Your airplane." This signals a change of controls is coming. The other pilot must respond back with "My airplane," acknowledging that they are now flying the aircraft.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
This is what we do with our children, especially around pools, at beaches, or on playground.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
When one of us needs to make a change in supervision or go do something different or help someone else, we announce it and make a verbal change: "Your Kate & Matt." And we wait for the other to respond "My Kate & Matt." This is the verbal and acknowledged shift of supervision duties for those two kids from one parent to the other. THIS SYSTEM WORKS.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
We never assume the other is watching.
We never assume they noticed we walked away.
We never assume the kids are being supervised. 
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
We state it clearly and wait for confirmation.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Especially in the summer, with all the added fun, consider using this trick with the other adults in your life. Let's not guess who is keeping the kids safe: let's know exactly whose role it is at every moment.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
"Your kids."
"My kids."

node.text:
I'm going to say it again and again: siblings need coaches, not referees.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
There's nothing more frustrating than hearing a sibling fight start. NOT THIS AGAIN. Their fighting has this way of filling us with such disappointment, anger, dread, and an overwhelming desire to just make it stop. Why can't they just get along?!
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Trust me. I get it. I live it.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
But I want to share with you the single best tip for raising siblings: SHIFT YOUR PERSPECTIVE. Instead of seeing siblings as this never ending fight that your left to referee daily, hourly, minutely, see it for what it is: the longest relationship your child will have with someone they DIDN'T PICK to live with.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
AND REMEMBER: You are dealing with 2+ people who are new to life, learning self-control, and have little to no problem solving skills. They need coaching. They need to be taught. They need help navigating this. Disagreements aren't something ONLY siblings have, it's just that in our adult relationships, we have grown up skills and know how to handle these moments. Kids don't... until we teach them.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
A few quick coaching tips:
✨Give them a change to fix the fight before you jump to intervene
✨Come to the situation calmly (be the calm presence they are not)
✨Get down on their level - don't hover above them - teach and model how to talk respectfully
✨Talk about ways to handle conflict AFTER OR AWAY FROM THE FIGHT
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
During times of peace, talk about solving problems. "Let's pretend a friend took your train. What do you do?" Lay the foundation when kids are calm and able to fully listen. They aren't born knowing these skills and they won't learn them unless we are willing to teach them.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
The sibling relationship: it is beautiful and complicated and so much more than fights over the red LEGO. This is the person they're going to learn the most about friendship & conflict from, and it is amazing what a little coaching can do.
